title: What percentage of the vote will Marine Le Pen win in the 2022 French presidential election runoff?
preds: Adjusting for Russian bank loans that won’t likely poll well

Polls showing between 40 an 45pc.  She could still win (small chance).  Her vote share is probably quite stable, it depends on how many people either don’t want to vote for either candidate or just don’t vote.  If that is a large group it will be good for LePen I think.  But support for LePen seems to be dropping.  Maybe she worried some people in the debate, even though she did better than last time. Am still keeping possibilities across all bins and weird things could happen.

A polling error the same magnitude as 2017 would put her very close to 40%. Given that she historically has always underperformed polls, *and* polls are trending strongly against her the last few weeks, I think the crowd is undercounting the odds of a <40% result here. My median guess for her final number is around 42.5%

Her floor is about 40 to 42 percent based on the polls.  The EU Parliament scandle is not having the affect I thought it could.  Yet, about 48 percent seems to be her ceiling based on the same polling.  There is currently a downward trend, and she is currently at about 44 percent.  So, 40 to 45 percent is most likely, followed by 35 to 40 percent if the downward trend continues.  The 45 to 50 range is only slightly above her current polling but again the trend is downward.  I do not see any last minute developments, which could help Le Pen.  Moreover, there are a lot of polls in a narrow range of since the debate last Wednesday.  Today there were six and Le Pen's average was 44.1 percent. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election#Second_round
There is a negative trend in Le Pen's poll estimates. I therefore addjust my forecast down.

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/apr/20/macron-and-le-pen-go-head-to-head-in-french-presidential-debate The latest opinion poll from Ipsos suggests Macron has a 12 point lead over Le Pen for the second-round vote, with him winning with 56% and her on 44%, with a 1.1% margin of error. However, 13% of those voters did not say for whom they would vote. Of those who said they would abstain or vote blank, 43% said they may change their mind on the day. A poll by BFMTV of a sample of its viewers found that 59% considered Macron convincing while 39% were won over by Le Pen.

Swapped my odds with Le Pen's current polling average at 45% on a multi-day downward trend.  In theory, I maybe should be putting some probability mass on the options directly above/below my guesses. Given the ordered categorical scoring rule, I'm not sure it's worth teasing out. Three years of polling averages ( https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/ ) consistently put Le Pen somewhere between 41 and 47 against Macron, and with the current polling average at 45%, even a systematic error of nearly five points in either direction still sticks to my chosen buckets.
Relationship between Le Pen and Putin seals her defeat.

The first poll is out with Le Pen < 43 (Ipsos has her at 42.5 now) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election#Macron_vs._Le_Pen  However... https://twitter.com/lennybronner/status/1517218220989726721

The world is changing and the French people at last have come to terms with the fact that they need a change in the political landscape as well.  This another Donald Trump moment. But don't be surprised as this moment has been brewing for years.
Le Pens lack of charisma plus a likely  ‘wave the flag’ syndrome’ should maintain a +10% gap… too high a hurdle, but smack dab on the edge of 2 bins
based on comments by @CJH @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1438239 and that Macron seems to have momentum.

https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/macron-s-polling-lead-over-le-pen-widens-ahead-of-france-s-sunday-runoff/47527848 An Ipsos poll saw Macron winning 56.5% of the vote, up half a point from Friday and up 3.5 points from 53 on April 8, two days before the first-round vote in which Macron and far-right candidate Le Pen qualified for the second round. An Opinionway poll put Macron at 56%, up two points on Friday. In an Ifop poll, Macron's share of voting intentions rose to 55%, up half a point from Monday and up three points compared to April 8. Macron's average score in the three polls rose to 55.83%, up more than three points compared to a 52.7% average of five polls of 52.70 on April 8. @tabhuth
most recent poll has her sitting at 44% per politico

Wikipedia has polling information in this race. Le Pen is starting to lose support.  This was predictable because Macron has only recently started campaigning full-time. Also, allegations of embezzlement by Le Pen while a member of the EU Parliament are beginning to get at least some coverage. 
 The poll drop appears to be at a very steep angle on the Wikipedia polling summary graph.  However, how far will it go? 
 There is a debate on Wednesday.  The reviews from the 2017 Macron-Le Pen debate had Macron as the overwhelming winner.  I could not find information on how the polls changed after the debate. 
 Nevertheless, Macron I suspect will win Wednesday’s debate.  Le Pen has tried to re-invent herself as more moderate.  I suspect the French are not buying it.  
 I think Le Pen's current polling average, which appears to be about 43-44 percent. (Look at the actual numbers.  The graph is an average and does not give enough weight to the most recent numbers.) 
 I suspect Le Pen's numbers will drop between another two and ten percent if I had to guess a 90 percent interval.  The range is eight percent so 43-44 percent adjusted for this range gives 41-42 to 35-36 percent.  The mid-point is about 38-39 percent.  However, the lower the numbers go, the more hard-core Le Pen's support.  So maybe 40-41 percent is a better guess.    
  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/04/french-election-marine-le-pen-and-emmanuel-macron-trade-insults-in-tv-debate  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election#Second_round

I was challenged by @tabhuth about my 0% forecast for over 50% (thank  you!).  Reconsidering my forecast . . .   I noticed that another forecaster said that her odds of winning were 15% (I don't remember who, or what their information source was for that statement), so that the odds for 50+ should be 15%.  I've been thinking about that.  For her to win, the polls would all have to be wrong.  Instead of getting 44-46% of the vote, she'd have to pick up 4-6%.  That would represent about a 10% error in the polls.  I have more confidence in French polling than that. Nevertheless, her odds of winning are not zero (as I have forecast)! Reasons I think Macron will win: -Macron seems to have more positive momentum -polling has consistently predicted he'd get 54-56% of the vote -analysis of the primary results suggests he'd win -LePen is allied with Putin who, with each passing day, is revealing himself more and more to be a butcher.   Putin is sinking her ship -LePen has recently been accused of mis-appropriation of funds and is under a cloud of scandal.  NEVERTHELESS,  LePen's chances of winning are more than my prior forecast of 0%.    Thank you for tapping me on the shoulder and making me think this through better!  Good luck to you!

https://www.rfi.fr/en/france/20220418-majority-of-mélenchon-s-voters-say-they-won-t-support-macron-according-to-poll-french-presidential-election Melenchon is urging his supporters to not support LePen, but is not endorsing Macron.  Consequently, 50-53% of his supporters not vote at all, while perhaps 30-33% will go to Macron, and the balance 13-16%  to LePen.
with current poll trend I'm thinking Le Pen gets something like 42.5% of the vote, with roughly even odds of getting <40 or >45
last poll showed Le Pen sitting at 46% - so potential to dip below 45% on the final count

The allegations that Le Pen embezzled money while at the EU parliament have not had much coverage in the French media since they broke two days ago.  The allegations are being covered but not as much as other election stories.  Also, I discovered allegations of embezzlement by Le Pen and her family are not new.  Therefore, the alleged bad character of Le Pen may already be baked into the polls.
She is a credible threat to win, but I do believe cooler heads will prevail.  Responsibility comes with their possession of nuclear weapons and position in NATO / EU

Spreading out a bit to mirror the economist model and acknowledge that I don't know much about how the vote will react to the Le Pen financial controversy (or very much at all about French politics, for that matter). https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022/forecast

As reported yesterday, Macron seems to have positive momentum. Meanwhile, or perhaps the reason for Macron's momentum is that LePen is getting bad PR.  Reuters reports that French prosecutors are examining a report by the European Union's anti-fraud agency accusing far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen and members of her party of misappropriating thousands of euros' worth of EU funds.
Downtrend / mean reversion in polls continuing

Marine Le Pen had 33pc of the vote in 2017.  I think she’ll do better this time. Melonchon’s communist vote was 22pc in round one, close to LePen.  Where his vote goes will have a big influence.  He has just held a poll of his voters where a large part went to abstentions.  But he made point of saying no one should vote for LePen even if Macron is also a bad choice https://f24.my/8YbK. So it feels like it would be hard to pick up a lot of this 22pc. The remainder of the vote at 26pc could go anywhere.  But if people don’t like the choice will they vote at all.  22pc abstained on the first round.  This could go down if people are disaffected,  it up if people feel strongly against LePen (or Macron), so I think vote levels will be about the same or a bit down. Let’s start with LePens first round 23pc.  If we assume LePen can pick up Zemmour’s 7pc this would give her 30pc.  So I give this as the minimum.  If we assume she gets half the remaining this is 38pc, this is likely. However it feels impossible to rule out a surprise.  I think proportion of votes on the 40’s is very likely.  And there is a chance of winning, just like Trump won in 2016 - we should remember that a low percentage of winning is not no chance.

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/04/16/world/europe/french-election-macron-le-pen.html?campaign_id=51&emc=edit_mbe_20220418&instance_id=58765&nl=morning-briefing%3A-europe-edition&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=89511&te=1&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1 Voter surveys show that his [Macron's] lead in the second round has widened. The French president would get 56 percent of the vote, compared with 44 for Ms. Le Pen — his largest lead since late March.

Nate Silver did an analysis where he added up the votes of all the pro-left (Macron-like) and pro-right (Le Pen-like) candidates and came up with 62 percent pro-Macron and 32 percent pro-Le Pen votes in the first round.  He also considered the pro-right candidates who asked their voters not to vote Le Pen in the second round.  The polls show 53.5 percent for Macron and 46.5 percent for Le Pen.  Silver put Le Pen's chance of winning at 10 to 15 percent.  Silver also noted a contradiction.  The polls in Europe tend to be fairly accurate per a 538 study, yet Le Pen did 5 points worse and Macron 5 points better in the 2017 election than the polling.    Yet, I found his overall argument convincing that Le Pen has a slight chance of winning.    It should also be noted Macron began campaigning very late during the first round so his poll numbers will likely rise.   I found less convincing the articles on such things as  Macron's COVID policies and Le Pen's and Macron’s  move to the center because the polls probably already account for these. Yet, there was a brand new story this morning about Le Pen misappropriating € 600,000 in public funds while a member of the European Parliament.  This could be devastating.   I was wondering how seriously to take these articles.  The oldest story is only 23 hours old and was published in a relatively unknown newspaper.  The major news outlets have not yet started to publish similar articles, except for DW news and the Guardian.  I was wondering if this suggested it was one of the stories that only outlets like Fox News, the Washington Examiner, the New York Post and OAN cover in the USA.  However, the Guardian and DW are reputable so there is probably something to it.  I guess the trick is to establish a 90-percent ceiling and floor if the election were held today and afterward consider the effects, if any, of the scandal . The absolute floor  should probably be the 32 percent of the pro-right vote in the first round.   I suspect she would get nearly all of those votes today. The absolute ceiling, despite Silver's statement that Le Pen could win, is likely less than 50 percent.  I understand some of the 62 percent who voted pro-left in the first round will not vote for Macron because they are angry with his COVID policies and move toward the center.  A 62 percent vote would leave Le Pen with a 38 percent ceiling.   That is an unlikely ceiling.   However, Macron started campaigning late (and he is probably very good or he would not be the incumbent), and therefore, the 53.5 percent is probably his floor.   Hence, Le Pen's 90 percent ceiling is probably around 46.5 percent.   The mid-point is 39.25 percent, right now.   The embezzlement case could backfire and help Le Pen if it is widely reported and turns out to be false. Yet, I think the EU prosecutors are probably non-partisan and conservative in cases like Le Pen's.   Therefore, the allegations will likely be deemed credible and harm her.   A 90 percent range for the harm the allegations could do, according to my best guess, is zero to 15 percent with a 7 percent mid-point.  Therefore, my new mid-point  becomes 32 percent, but with a wide range, especially on the upside because it might not happen and some French voters are extremely pro-right. So, lets start with 39.25 rounded to 39 percent.  The 7 percent mid-point for the effects of a scandal is probably the absolute bottom right now. This is a question that could need a lot more updating than usual because of the abrupt EU scandal. Surprisingly, the war in Ukraine does not seem to have hurt Le Pen—or any of the other EU authoritarians—so far.

The current polls have Le pen at slightly above 45%. I am expecting Le Pen to underperform by a few points because of the following reason that is informed by the late surge in Melenchon votes in the first round. People who will vote Le Pen will most likely have already decided to do so, so they are factored in to the numbers already. People who do not want to vote for Le Pen or Macron might only decide to vote against Le Pen right before the election. Therefore, they do not appear in the polls right now. On the other hand, I expect fewer people to decide to vote against Macron at the last moment.
Most of the voters who voted for the far-leftist Melechon are most likely to vote against Le Pen, so Macron will win the second round just barely.  especially when Melechon publicly endorsed Macron.

Polling suggests this will be a close race. I'm erring on the side of a Macron victory because I think final voting may learn more toward the status quo. I haven't factored in the effects of Macron's latest statesman-like activities in engaging with Putin.

- In the last election, she got 33.90%.
- When we sum up all the right-wing votes, Le Pen may get around 30% (National Rally, Reconquête, and maybe some extra votes).
- Left-wing party members called for not voting for Le pen.
- I guess Marcon voters keep voting for him.
- While Macron trounced Le Pen in 2017, and improved on his initial numbers from the last election, polls are suggesting a much tighter race this time around (13th of April)
- 54 percent for Marcon 15th of April
- Current polls suggest a Saddle point of Le Pen's percentage (15 th of April)
- Le Pen is eager to highlight rising energy and food costs that have hit low-income households especially hard in recent weeks -> Which may lead low-income households to vote for her

She got around a third in the last runoff and the bias this a time will be for a much better result.  While Macron is no prize, the war in Ukraine will likely temper the potential for an upset and an exit from NATO.
current polls are indicating a pretty close contest between Macron and LePen - with Macron leading 51%/49%
Macron winning run-off with 53% of vote • FRANCE 24 English

Sarko's growing relationship with Macron will keep this on the lower side of 40% but less than 45%. And no Steve Bannon telling her when to
stand in front of the elevator going up to Trumps sute in the tower.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election#Macron_vs._Le_Pen Polls taken on or after 10 April, when the first round results were known, have Le Pen getting between 45 and 49 percent, with an average of 46.5%

Looking at the Politico Poll-of-Polls going back all the way to 2019, Le Pen quite consistently sits in a zone above 40% and below 50% matched up against Macron. Both are known entities. There isn't likely to be any surprise to knock the results out of the established zone over the next twelve days. https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/

27pc Macron, 23pc LePen, 22pc Melonchon.  Melonchon nearly made it!   There are several key deciders for me
1) Where Melochons voters go.  There is talk of people who are left leaning but associate more with LePen than Macron and might vote for her.  If a good proportion Melonchon communist vote goes to her rather than Macron which would be more logical, it will be very close. 
2) How LePen performs in the debates. She was terrible last time and had no idea how to deal with Macron.  And as Macron was an unknown quantity then with no history it was hard to attack him.  This time she has ammunition and will have learnt from last time and no doubt will have prepared carefully.  She has to do well there.
3) Familiarity.  There are a lot of of people who really don’t like Macron and now that LePen has been around for three elections and people are familiar with her, and she’s learnt to find ways to put less people off, I think she could pull it off.
4) The blank votes and non voters.  If peoples don’t bother to turn out LePen has a better chance. I’m giving LePen a reasonable chance at the moment.  Update after the debates. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_French_presidential_election#Opinion_polls

Le Pen, with 33.8% of the popular vote in 2017 and as an established right wing candidate with bad brand pedigree.
Is Le Pen center enough now?
Is Macron disliked enough now?
How much ground is Le Pen likely to make up on the previous 32 point deficit? A win would require a 50.8% improvement over last election. Is.... *France* that right wing? History doesn't repeat, but often rhymes: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_French_presidential_election

Right now, polling between Macon and Le Pen is within the margin of error. This is a safe way to express dissatisfaction when you know you candidate will win. For this second round, I think most French voters will focus on who has the better plan for France and France's role within the EU. I suspect that's when all the far right stuff comes out and her number drop out of the near tie.

My reasoning is that the polls will show (are showing) Le Pen very close to Macron and this will push oppositors of Le Pen to reluctantly vote for Macron in an attempt to stop her. The end result will be a much stronger vote for Macron than anticipated.

In 2017, Macron had 24% in the first round, and Le Pen 21.3%. There were another 6.4% votes cast for the far right (Dupont-Aignan and Arthaud-Poutou).  Melenchon recorded 19.6% and the traditional moderate right 20%. This gave a likely vote split of 44 to 27.7 with other votes (mainly left leaning up for grabs). In the second round Macron had 66.1% of the votes and Le Pen 33.9%.  This means Le Pen picked up the other far right votes and 22% of the other available votes. This time. Macron has 27.8% and another 4.8% of the traditional right. (32.6%). Le Pen has 23.1% plus 10% of other far right votes) for 33.1%.  If Le Pen wins the same 22% of other votes that is 7.5% and 40.6% and at 45% of these available votes Le Pen would reach 48.6%. Le Pen needs to pick up c35% of the available votes to reach the 45%+ bucket.

Le Pen has to make up 1.6m votes on Macro who is on 9.8m.
She could get up to 3.2m increase from Zemmour and Dupont-Aignan voters, but
Macro likely to get a share of 12.0m extra votes from a wide range of other candidates.
Got to aim off a bit because people are unpredictable.
The answer to this question might be very heavily affected by abstention rates. If voters transferred votes predictably and automatically and the same people abstained as before I'd predict Macro 22m / Pen 11.4m so 33% for Pen.
I'm coming to see Pen's credible range of possible scores as 33% to 50.5%. 
And guessing that it will land about 46%.
Macron is still better placed ........... he had slipped and has rebounded

Even though Macron has received most of the endorsements from the unsuccessful parties, he has the hurdle of voter apathy.  Five years ago he was the new and exciting candidate but now doesn't have that momentum. There may be more motivation amongst Zemmour's supporters making this a closer contest.

Extrapolating from the vote yesterday.   Le Pen got 45.4% of the votes cast for either her or Macron.   Will she get a higher % of the remaining votes than Macron does, given that he has been endorsed by all the other candidates except Zemmour, who only got 7% of the vote?  I doubt it.

I agree with @MrLittleTexas - around 45% seems highly likely at the moment. Though I am inclined to believe that Le Pen will win slightly less than 45% because:  i) All candidates except Zemmour endorsed Macron for the runoff (https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20220410-french-socialist-green-right-wing-candidates-back-macron-in-election-run-off-against-le-pen). I know adding percentages in the first round is not really accurate to predict the outcome of a second round, but this is interesting: Le Pen and Zemmour only obtained about 30% of the vote combined. And the options seemed pretty nuanced in left-wing/right-wing terms. I find it hard to imagine that many Mélenchon or Jadot voters will decide to change their mind and support Le Pen in the runoff. ii) Both Le Pen and Zemmour underperformed with respect to predictions based on polls (https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022/forecast). On the other hand, both Macron and Mélenchon overperformed.
My guess is it'll be right around 45%
